video.title: JavaScript ES6, ES7, ES8: Learn to Code on the Bleeding Edge (Full Course)
video.description:
This course will teach you the most modern features of JavaScript, also known as ES6+. You can also take the interactive version of the course here: https://scrimba.com/g/gintrotoes6

JavaScript is one of the most popular programming languages in the world. It’s used almost everywhere: from large-scale web applications to complex servers to mobile and IoT devices.

⭐️ Course content ⭐️

⌨️ Template Literals (1:06)
⌨️ Destructuring (5:32)
⌨️ Object Literal (9:42)
⌨️ For of loop (13:44)
⌨️ Spread operator (17:51) 
⌨️ Rest operator (20:57)
⌨️ Arrow Functions (23:02)
⌨️ Default Params (25:50)
⌨️ Array.includes() (27:44)
⌨️ Let & const (28:58)
⌨️ Export & import (32:53)
⌨️ String.padStrart(), String.padEnd() (35:29)
⌨️ Classes (38:05)
⌨️ Trailing commas (49:59)
⌨️ Async/Await (51:27)
⌨️ Sets (1:01:19)
⌨️ What's Next (1:04:08)

Follow the instructor Dylan Israel on Twitter here: https://twitter.com/PizzaPokerGuy

Check out Dylan's intro to JavaScript course: https://youtu.be/_y9oxzTGERs

Check out Dylan's YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5Wi_NYysX-LfcqT3Hq9Faw

If you want to learn more about JavaScript, check out these playlists on our channel:
▶JavaScript Basics: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list...
▶ES6: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list...
▶Design Patterns: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list...
▶Data Structures and Algorithms: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list...
▶Clean Code: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list...

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: Mathieu Guignès
topLevelComment.text:
Yes trailing commas is an awesome feature! I've been struggling with this comma issue in other languages, and even when writing JSON files... When you're adding, then removing, trial and error, rewriting code, etc, it's so frustrating when you forget a stupid comma.
Or even when generating  SQL code for example, in a loop, with multiple select columns or ORDER BY, you need the conditionally write your commas in between and remove the last one... Its just a pain

topLevelComment.author: SF CS
topLevelComment.text:
I'm a professional backend dev with a primary focus on php. Trailing Commas can be a blessing depending on your preference. Say you have created an array with trailing commas and newlines:

const array = [
    1,
    2,
    3,
]

Suppose you had to add an element to this array on a later revision, it is easier to start editing beginning with an enter press and end with a comma than vise-versa (at least for me). But the real benefit comes from when you have to remove an element from the end. You can achieve that with a single keyboard shortcut via your editor without having to do extra work for clearing a comma from above line. It is a nice QoL feature I love, but it may not be necessary for everyone.

topLevelComment.author: Mahmoud Matar
topLevelComment.text:
If anyone has a problem with import/export, try the following solution:
> open cmd
> navigate to the project folder
> type 'npm init' and click enter
(you will notice a file called package.json created)
> open package.json and under "name": "<project name>", type: "type": "module",

save and recompile. It should be solved.

topLevelComment.author: NotMe
topLevelComment.text:
What do you use in order to have all those packages available for you to use in your project?
When I use fetch, or import/export I get errors saying 'fetch is not defined' and something like 'cannot import outside module'.
I'm used to doing this in ReactJS so I have a fully fleshed out asset pipeline and package.json that allows me to use things like fetch, axios, import/export but how do you have it working the way you do?

replies.author: Doug Jones
replies.text: fetch is not part of node by default. You must add "node-fetch" to your package.json ("npm install node-fetch") and then use "import fetch from "node-fetch" in your example. Then it should work.

topLevelComment.author: Mohit Kamal
topLevelComment.text:
I want to point out one thing.
You said that var is hoisted and let and const aren't. 

But it's not true.

All variable declarations are hoisted in their lexical context. The only difference between var and let hoisting is that var, when hoisted, is initialized by undefined. But let is not initialized. So we get a Reference Error when we try to access a let variable before initialization. 

:) Please correct me if I am wrong anywhere

topLevelComment.author: Aloan Moreira
topLevelComment.text:
hey, a dizzy question?! :D : There is a game engine (I personally LOVE it and I think it is the best, for being simple, fast and practical) called CopperCube. It works only with JavaScript. So my question is... I have not read anywhere if it "accepts" different javascript versions (6,7,8)
In other words, you know like Minecraft has pissed me off a lot because Mods made for it only work as long as there is no update. Which is impossible, since Minecraft updates happen a lot. So a mod brakes at each update. Does that happen with javascript? so do I have to find out what javascript version CopperCube "supports" or can I run any version in it? (hope I wasn't so confusing)

replies.author: Navjot Singh
replies.text: All features es6 is still not fully supported, what people are doing is they are using engines (like Babel) to compile their es6 code to compliant es5 code, because es5 is currently still more supported than es6(and anything higher).

topLevelComment.author: Manasa n
NewLondonWeb
topLevelComment.text: Excellent tutorial! I have found that for-of when used with a json object returned from a database, destructured in the for loop and the return of a template string useful for quickly putting up a list of returned records. ie.     let result ="";  const arry=[{name: "John", address:"123 any-street"}, {name:"Jane", address:"124 any-street"}];  for({name, address} of arry){ result += `$(name) lives at $(address)  /  ` }; console.log(result); // John lives at 123 any-street  / Jane lives at 124 any-street.   The template string could have,  just as easily,  popped the vars into html code then, using  innerHTML,  output it to the web page as a grid of cards or a list etc.
